questions.text:
A 45-year-old chronic kidney disease patient with diabetes is now prescribed DPP-4 inhibitors. Which of the following DPP-4 inhibitors is best suited for this patient?

DPP-4 - dipeptidyl-peptidase-4
questions.solution:
Linagliptin is preferred in this patient as it does not require dose adjustment in patients with renal failure.

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated. It binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system. Hence, no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure.

Other DPP-4 inhibitors (sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin) show renal elimination and therefore require dose reduction in renal failure.

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors enhance the release of insulin postprandially, decreases glucagon, and thereby lower mealtime as well as fasting glucose. They are weight neutral.

questions.text: An elderly woman was hospitalized for pneumonia and is on antibiotic therapy with clindamycin. She now complains of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Her colonoscopy findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following toxins is most commonly associated with her GI symptoms?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image given above showing yellow plaques and nodules on the mucosa are suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis. It is usually caused by Clostridium difficile. The pathogenesis is mediated by the enterotoxins - toxin A and toxin B.

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers. It can persist on surfaces for months. Risk factors include poor hand hygiene, old age, and gastrointestinal surgery.

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins—toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic. 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A young boy presents with pain in his fingers and toes. On examination, he had pallor and icterus. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike. Peripheral smear findings are given below.  What is the likely mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike and peripheral smear showing sickle-shaped cells are suggestive of sickle cell disease. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

Factors that predispose to sickling are infection, dehydration, and acidosis.

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Painful bone crisis- hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • The aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    • Adolescence or early adulthood- autosplenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled red cells on the peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike. The changes in the skull resemble a crewcut in radiographic studies as a result of compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.

The image given below shows the sickling of RBCs in sickle cell disease.

The image given below shows Howell-Jolly bodies seen in asplenia.

Note: The sickle cell trait protects against falciparum malaria in certain African populations.

questions.text:
A young man with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. A bolus of both normal saline and IV short-acting insulin is administered. What is the next step in management?

Random blood sugar: 500mg/dl
Urine ketones ++
Serum potassium - 5.4mEq/L

choices.text: Start normal saline infusion and continuous insulin infusion
Administer bicarbonate 50 mEq in sterile water
Start continuous insulin infusion and administer potassium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The next step in management is to start normal saline infusion and continuous insulin infusion.

DKA is a complication of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus common in type 1 diabetes mellitus but can also occur in type 2. It occurs in the setting of absolute or relative insulin deficiency along with glucagon excess leading to extreme hyperglycemia.

Clinical features include severe nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and severe volume depletion. Signs include Kussmaul breathing, fruity odor on the patient’s breath, tachycardia, dehydration, and hypotension. 

The diagnosis of DKA is made based on the following parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia >250 mg/dL
  • Ketosis or ketones in the urine
  • Metabolic acidosis with pH <7.4 and HCO3 <15 mEq/L
  • High anion gap due to ketoacids and lactic acidosis

Pseudohyponatremia (dilutional) is seen as a result of hyperglycemia due to osmotic shift. Normal sodium levels on admission indicate severe dehydration. Potassium levels at presentation may be normal or elevated despite total body deficit, due to intracellular shift. If the initial serum potassium <3.3 mEq/L, insulin should be administered only after the correction of hypokalemia. This is because treatment with insulin and fluids can worsen hypokalemia.

The mainstay management of diabetic ketoacidosis includes urgent fluid resuscitation and maintenance, along with insulin therapy, electrolyte replacement, and supportive care. The algorithm of management is given below. 

Criteria for resolution of ketoacidosis include:
  • Blood glucose <200 mg/dL, and
  • Two of the following criteria:
    • Serum bicarbonate level ≥15 mEq/L
    • Venous pH >7.3
    • Anion gap ≤12 mEq/L

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with symptoms of fatigue and headache. On further examination, he is found to have pallor, tingling, and numbness over his extremities. Peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia. Laboratory findings revealed methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 15 years ago and has been taking metformin. Which of the following is most likely deficient in him?
questions.solution:
A vitamin B12/ cobalamin deficiency is most likely seen in him.

The given clinical features of peripheral neuropathy, peripheral smear finding of macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils, methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine, and history of metformin intake after being diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus indicate a vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Its absorption in the terminal ileum is facilitated by the presence of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells in the stomach. There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA.

The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine. Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well.

Risk factors for B12 deficiency include gastric atrophy (pernicious anemia), terminal ileal disease, strict vegetarianism, acid-reducing drugs (e.g., H2 blockers), and prolonged use of metformin. The interference by metformin on calcium-dependent membrane action is responsible for vitamin B12-intrinsic factor malabsorption in the terminal ileum.

On examination, patients present anemia, fatigue, and pallor symptoms. Other presenting complaints may include peripheral neuropathy, glossitis, diarrhea, headaches, neuropsychiatric disturbances like dementia, and subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord (SACD) leading to ataxia. A peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B9 (Folic acid) deficiency can also be seen in patients on prolonged use of metformin and can cause macrocytic anemia. Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid differentiates between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Folate deficiency results in:

  • Megaloblastic anemia 
  • Homocystenemia
  • Neural tube defects (spina bifida, Anencephaly) in the fetus.

Option C: A patient with pyridoxine/ Vitamin B6 deficiency presents with symptoms of seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and microcytic anemia.

Option D: A patient with thiamine/ Vitamin B1 deficiency presents either dry Beriberi with predominantly neurological symptoms like neuropathy, muscle weakness and wasting or wet Beriberi with predominant cardiac symptoms like cardiomegaly, tachycardia, high output congestive cardiac failure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with a history of tremors, palpitation, and difficulty in closing his eyes for the past 1 month. On examination, you note the following finding as shown in the image given below. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The given image shows lid retraction in the right eye, which is known as Dalrymple's sign.

It is the commonest and earliest sign of Grave's ophthalmopathy. It is due to overactivity of levator aponeurosis and Müller's muscle. Here the upper lid margin is at level with or above the superior limbus, causing the upper sclera to become visible (scleral show).

Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in hyperthyroidism. In this condition, autoantibodies bind to thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors and stimulate the secretion of thyroid hormone. 

Thyroid ophthalmopathy or thyroid eye disease can be seen in Graves' disease or even in euthyroid/ hypothyroid patients. Women and smokers are at higher risk of developing Grave's ophthalmopathy (otherwise known as thyroid eye disease). 

Thyroid function tests and a thyroid autoantibody assay should be done to assess thyroid hormone status. 

Control of hyperthyroidism is effective in management. Injecting botulinum toxin to levator aponeurosis and Müller's muscle may be done as a temporary measure. 

The other options are all signs associated with Grave's disease but do not correlate with the given image.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is used to measure intracellular fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Deuterium oxide and inulin are the indicators used for the measurement of intracellular fluid volume (ICF).

The ICF cannot be measured directly. It is calculated by subtracting the extracellular fluid volume (ECF) from the total body water (TBW).

ICF  = TBW - ECF

Indicators used for the measurement of TBW are:

  • Tritium oxide (3H2O)
  • Deuterium oxide (2H2O)
  • Antipyrine

Indicators used for the measurement of ECF are:

  • 22Na
  • 125I-iothalamate
  • Thiosulfate
  • Inulin

Other options:

Option A: Tritium oxide and Evans blue are used for the measurement of TBW and plasma volume respectively.

Option C: Inulin and 125I-albumin are used for the measurement of ECF volume and plasma volume respectively, and together, they are used to calculate the interstitial fluid volume (ECF-plasma volume).

Option D: Thiosulfate and Evans blue are used for the measurement of ECF volume and plasma volume respectively, and together, they are used to calculate the interstitial fluid volume (ECF-plasma volume).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with COVID-19 infection develops shortness of breath and is brought to the hospital. His SpO2 increases from 81% to 83% on administering oxygen via facemask at 10 L/min. The decision to deliver oxygen using the device shown below is made. What is its oxygen delivery rate?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is high-flow nasal cannula. It delivers oxygen at 40-60 L/min. This patient has persistent hypoxia after an adequate trial of standard oxygen therapy and should be started on high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy. 

High flow nasal cannula is a mode of respiratory support used in the management of acute respiratory failure. It delivers humidified gas via the nasal cannula at high flow rates.

  • HFNC can deliver oxygen at 40 L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.
  • The benefits of HFNC include reduced work of breathing, improved gas exchange by nasopharyngeal dead-space washout, and decreased energy required to humidify and heat respiratory gases.

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier (named PMH200), a nasal cannula (No. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).

questions.text: Which national health program's logo is shown below?
questions.solution:
The given logo is of the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP).

The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) was started in the year 1997 and aims at diagnosing and caring for TB cases both in the public and private sectors. It undertook a DOTS (Directly Observed Therapy Short course) strategy that ensures a cure by providing and confirming that the most effective medicine is taken. The logo of DOTS is shown below.

RNTCP was renamed National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) on 1st January 2020 with the aim to eliminate TB by 2025, 5 years ahead of the WHO End TB strategy which is the global target. In May 2014, the WHO launched the End TB strategy, which formed a framework to guide countries toward ending the TB epidemic by decreasing TB mortality, and incidence and eliminating the financial burden of the disease. The logo of the End TB strategy is shown below. 

The National Tobacco Control Programme (NTCP) was launched by the government in 2007-08 during the 11th five-year plan, with the aim to generate awareness about the harmful effects of tobacco consumption and smoking. It also aimed to reduce the production and supply of tobacco products and facilitate the implementation of strategies for the prevention and control of tobacco advocated by the WHO framework convention on tobacco control. 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

questions.text: A patient was started on a drug for the treatment of glaucoma. He presents with complaints of extensive loss of orbital fat giving the appearance of a sunken eye. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this side effect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of orbital fat atrophy and it is seen with topical PGF2α (prostaglandin) analogs like latanoprost.

Topical PGF2 alpha (prostaglandin) analogs are used as a first line in glaucoma. Latanoprost is the most commonly used anti-glaucoma medication. Other prostaglandin analogues are travoprost, bimatoprost, tafluprost, and unoprostone.

Mechanism of action: It reduces intraocular pressure by altering the ciliary muscle tension and improving the outflow of the aqueous humor.

Adverse effects:

  • Blurring of vision
  • Iris pigmentation
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes
  • Macular edema especially in aphakic patients. 
  • Orbital fat atrophy

Other options:

Option A: Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker used topically in glaucoma. Ocular adverse effects of beta-blockers include dryness and redness of the eye, stinging, corneal hypoesthesia, blurred vision, and allergic blepharoconjunctivitis. Systemic side effects like bradycardia and bronchospasm may be seen due to absorption through the nasolacrimal duct.

Option B: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent and adverse effects are corneal edema, miosis, induced myopia, and retinal detachment.

Option C: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and reduces intraocular pressure by reducing the aqueous humor formation. It is given orally and the systemic adverse effects are anorexia, paresthesia, hypokalemia, acidosis, and depression.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with multibacillary leprosy. For how long should she be treated and monitored for relapse, respectively?
questions.solution:
A patient with multibacillary leprosy should be treated for 12 months and monitored for relapse for at least 5 years.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease that mainly affects the skin, the peripheral nerves, upper respiratory tract mucosa, and the eyes caused by Mycobacterium leprae. If left untreated, it can lead to permanent damage to the skin, nerves, limbs, and eyes.

Leprosy is classified as paucibacillary (PB) or multibacillary (MB). Paucibacillary leprosy refers to cases with 1-5 skin lesions, no or only 1 involved nerve, with no bacilli in a skin smear. Multibacillary leprosy refers to cases with >5 skin lesions, with >1 nerve involvement, or with the presence of bacilli in the skin smear, irrespective of the number of skin lesions.

WHO recommends multidrug therapy (MDT) for the treatment of leprosy. The currently recommended MDT regimen includes dapsone, rifampicin and clofazimine. It is given for 6 months in paucibacillary leprosy and 12 months for multibacillary cases. 

The majority of the cases are cured following MDT, however, relapse may occur. A multibacillary patient has to be monitored for 5 years and the paucibacillary patient has to be monitored for 2 years after completion of treatment.

The blister pack provided for the treatment of multibacillary leprosy is shown below.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient who is under mechanical positive pressure ventilation developed a sudden drop in saturation. BP is 90/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and pulse rate is 120 bpm. The chest x-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis and the immediate step of management for this patient?

choices.text: Right-sided tension pneumothorax; Chest tube insertion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray points to a diagnosis of left-sided tension pneumothorax. Immediate needle thoracostomy with a wide-bore needle in the fifth intercostal space should be done in order to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

The given x-ray features showing a well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side with tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side, along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed while waiting for radiological confirmation. Imaging modalities used are ultrasound–extended focused assessment with sonar for trauma (eFAST), chest x-ray, and spiral CT.

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e. air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately leads to the collapse of the affected lung.

It usually occurs following penetrating or blunt chest trauma, iatrogenic lung injury, or mechanical positive pressure ventilation.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distension
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury 
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

Management of tension pneumothorax:

  • Immediate management- needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line.
  • Definitive management- tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety, identified as a triangle that lies anterior to the mid-axillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

The x-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side.

Other options:

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad). The breath sounds are absent in tension pneumothorax while they are present in cardiac tamponade. Pericardiocentesis is done in cases of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination of the nose, she has roomy nasal cavities, foul-smelling discharge, and dry greenish crusts. She is also found to have merciful anosmia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of merciful anosmia, foul-smelling discharge, and roomy nasal cavities, with dry greenish crusts, points to a diagnosis of atrophic rhinitis.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The exact etiology of this condition is not known. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. 

Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

Treatment:

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water.
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.
  • Surgical management:
    • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
    • Modified Young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort of complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
    • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

Other options:

Option B: Nasal polyps are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps. They present with a polypoid mass in the nose.

Option C: Allergic rhinitis is associated with inferior turbinate hypertrophy and can cause chronic nasal obstruction. It is characterized by watery nasal discharge, sneezing, and itching in the nose.

Option D: Foreign body nose is commonly seen in children. The child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: A mother brings her 7-year-old daughter with the complaint that the child wakes up at night screaming, sweating, and terrified. She does not respond to the comforting efforts by her parents. She does not recall the episode in the morning. In which stage of sleep do the episodes experienced by the daughter occur?
questions.solution:
The child who wakes up with intense fear and signs of arousal such as sweating, and does not recall the event in the morning is experiencing sleep terrors or night terrors. Night terrors occur in deep sleep (stages 3 and 4 of NREM sleep).

Sleep terror or night terror is an NREM sleep arousal disorder. In this condition, the patient experiences sudden arousal with intense fearfulness. They may have a piercing scream or cry with manifestations of intense anxiety.

On arousal, they sit up in bed, are unresponsive to stimuli, and are confused and disoriented on awakening. Autonomic disturbances may be present. If vocal, they are incoherent. The patient cannot generally be awakened and efforts to calm them are not successful.  

Sleep terrors only have brief frightening or vivid images, or may not have imagery at all. It can be provoked by sleep deprivation, fever, and central nervous system depressant withdrawal. 

Nightmares have elaborate dream sequences without autonomic disturbances. They occur in REM sleep. The patient can be aroused and typically remembers the dream.

The various stages of sleep and their appearance on EEG are summarized in the image below.

questions.text: A person working in the smelting industry presents with the finding as shown below. She also complains of painful paresthesia over the hands and feet. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing hyperkeratosis of palms are suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning.

Acute poisoning: Resembles cholera; garlicky odor.

Chronic poisoning:

  • Raindrop pigmentation is seen on temples, eyelids, and neck
  • Aldrich-Mee’s lines (transverse white striae on the fingernails)
  • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles
  • Painful paresthesia of hands and feet
  • The red velvety appearance of the stomach
  • Blackfoot disease - a gangrenous condition affecting the extremities

Tests to detect Arsenic poisoning:

  • Marsh test and Reinsch test

Treatment:

  • Freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide
  • BAL (British anti-Lewisite)
  • Penicillamine (If BAL is not available)

questions.text:
A 33-year-old lady comes for a routine check-up at 34 weeks of gestation when her blood pressure is found to be 170/118 mmHg. Her urine analysis shows proteinuria 3+. Which of the following statements are true about the management of this situation?
  1. Oral Captopril can be used as a second-line drug.
  2. Labetalol is safe in asthmatics and cardiac failure patients.
  3. The maximum dose of labetalol that can be given is 300 mg.
  4. Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice.
  5. Sodium nitroprusside is the first-line drug.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe pre-eclampsia with hypertensive crisis (BP>160/110 mmHg). Intravenous Labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling blood pressure in severe pre-eclampsia and the maximum dose that can be given is 300 mg. Therefore, options 3 and 4 are correct. 

Drugs used in the management of hypertensive crisis.

Drug Onset of Action  Dose schedule  Maximum dose  Maintainance Dose 
Labetalol 5 mins 10-20 mg IV every 10 mins  300 mg IV 40 mg/hr
Hydralazine 10 mins 5 mg IV every 30 mins  30 mg IV 10 mg/hr
Nifedipine 10 mins  10-20 mg oral, can be repeated in 30 mins  240 mg/24 hours  4-6 hour intervals 
Nitroglycerin 0.5-5mins  5 mcg/min IV Short-term therapy when other drugs failed  
Sodium Nitroprusside  0.5-5mins  0.25-5 mcg/kg/min IV Short-term therapy when other drugs failed  

 

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and is hence contraindicated in pregnancy.

Labetalol is avoided in women having asthma or cardiac failure.

Sodium nitroprusside is only given after treatment with other drugs has failed.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with dyspnea on exertion and bluish discoloration of lips, which is relieved on squatting. A chest x-ray is taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the primary defect responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Anterior deviation of the infundibular septum
Pulmonary venous connection to the SVC
Ostium secundum defect in the fossa ovalis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing cyanotic spells and chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette are suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition and has been classically characterized by the following components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks (hypoxic, “blue,” or “tet” spells) are a problem during the 1st year of life and may last from a few minutes to a few hours. The child can have shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips which is relieved on squatting. Short episodes are followed by generalized weakness and sleep. Severe spells may progress to unconsciousness and occasionally to convulsions or hemiparesis.

Older children with tetralogy of Fallot characteristically increase pulmonary blood flow by squatting. Squatting is a compensatory mechanism, it increases peripheral vascular resistance (PVR) and thus decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Chest X-ray describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot.
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

Other options:

Option B - A pulmonary venous connection to the superior vena cava (SVC) is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). It is a cyanotic congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins drain directly into the right atrium, coronary sinus, SVC, IVC, or ductus venosus.

On chest x-ray, supracardiac TAPVR presents with the snowman appearance of the heart which is as shown below

Option C - A downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve is seen in Ebstein anomaly, a cyanotic heart disease. Infants with severe disease present with marked cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly, and long holosystolic murmurs. Death may result from cardiac failure, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypoplasia. 

Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly caused by enlargement of the right atrium giving rise to a massive box-shaped cardiac shadow as shown below.

Option D - An ostium secondum defect in the fossa ovalis is the most common site of atrial septal defects (ASD). ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum causing a left-to-right shunt.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A widely fixed and split S2 is characteristic. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found. A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the emergency department after suffering a penetrating injury to the neck. On examination, there is a small laceration just above the cricoid cartilage. His vitals were found to be stable. Examination revealed active bleeding from the site of injury. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of penetrating neck injury just above the cricoid cartilage corresponds to zone II neck injury. Although the patient is hemodynamically stable, the presence of hard signs such as active bleeding warrants immediate neck exploration as the next step of management.

Neck trauma is classified based on the different regions of the neck:

  • Zone I: thoracic inlet to cricoid, associated with maximum mortality. It contains large vascular structures as well as the trachea and oesophagus.
  • Zone II: cricoid cartilage to the angle of the mandible, most commonly prone to injury and most easily accessible for surgery. It contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and structures of the aerodigestive tract.
  • Zone III: angle of the mandible to the base of the skull. Structures within zone III include blood vessels that are difficult to expose surgically.

The following are the indications for immediate surgical exploration of neck trauma. They are also known as the hard signs of neck trauma:

  • Active bleeding 
  • Expanding or pulsatile hematoma
  • Air bubbling from penetrating injury
  • Massive subcutaneous emphysema
  • Hematemesis
  • Presence of neurological deficit
  • Fluid-resistant hemorrhagic shock
  • Audible bruit or palpable thrill
  • Airway compromise

Management:

  •  If the patient is hemodynamically unstable or presence of any hard signs - neck exploration.
  •  If the patient is stable- angiography and angioembolization are indicated. If it fails, then neck exploration should be done.

questions.text: A young girl presented with an inability to abduct her right thumb following a supracondylar fracture of her right humerus. The following test was done on her and found to be positive. What is the nerve likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a positive pen test are suggestive of the weakness of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle. The nerve likely to be injured in this case is the median nerve.

To perform the pen test, the hand is held flat with the palm facing upwards. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb. If the patient is unable to touch the pen, it signifies a positive pen test.

Median nerve lesions can be high lesions or low lesions depending on the site of injury.

Low lesions occur due to injuries at the distal 1/3rd of the forearm such as carpal dislocation or cut wound of the wrist. There will be paralysis of the hand muscles and the patient will be unable to abduct the thumb. There is also a loss of sensation over the radial 3½ digits. The forearm muscles supplied by the median nerve are spared in these lesions. Wasting of thenar eminence is seen in long-standing cases.

High lesions occur due to injuries above the elbow such as forearm fractures or elbow dislocation. There is paralysis of the forearm muscles along with all the features of low lesions.

Muscles supplied by the median nerve are given in the table:

In the arm No muscles
Proximal 1/3rd of the forearm All the flexor muscles of the proximal forearm, except the flexor carpi ulnaris and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus
Distal 1/3rd of the forearm  No muscles
In the hand

Abductor pollicis brevis
Opponens pollicis
Flexor pollicis brevis
First two lumbricals

Other tests for median nerve: 

Pointing index sign or Oschner’s clasp test - the patient is asked to clasp both hands together. When this is done the index and the middle finger fail to flex due to the loss of action of long finger flexors which are supplied by the median nerve. 

Benediction test - due to loss of activity of the long finger flexors the patient is unable to flex the index and middle finger on lifting the hand. As this is the position a clergyman uses to bless the couple during the marriage, it is called the benediction test.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is being evaluated for congenital ptosis. On examination, there is retraction of the ptotic lid when she is asked to move her jaw from side to side. It is inferred that there is a misdirection of the nerve supplying the jaw muscles to the levator palpebrae muscle. Identify the misdirected nerve.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking syndrome. The misdirected cranial nerve supplying the jaw muscles is the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve labeled as '4'.

Trigeminal nerve

The trigeminal nerve leaves the anterior aspect of the pons as a small motor root and a large sensory root. The nerve passes forward out of the posterior cranial fossa and rests on the upper surface of the apex of the petrous part of the temporal bone in the middle cranial fossa. The large sensory root now expands to form the crescent-shaped trigeminal ganglion, which lies within a pouch of dura mater called the trigeminal or Meckel cave. The ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves arise from the anterior border of the ganglion.

Branches of the trigeminal nerve

  • The ophthalmic nerve (V1)
    • Leaves the skull through the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbital cavity.
    • Contains only sensory fibers
      • Cornea
      • Skin of forehead, scalp, eyelids, and nose
      • Mucous membrane of paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
  • The maxillary nerve (V2)
    • Leaves the skull through the foramen rotundum.
    • Contains only sensory fibers from
      • Teeth of upper jaw
      • Skin of face over maxilla
      • Mucous membrane of nose, the maxillary sinus, and palate
  • The mandibular nerve (V3)
    • Leaves the skull through the foramen ovale.
    • Contains both sensory and motor fibers.
    • Sensory from
      • Skin of cheek, over mandible and side of head
      • Teeth of lower jaw and temporomandibular joint
      • Mucous membrane of mouth and anterior part of tongue
    • Motor to
      • Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masseter and temporalis)
      • Tensor tympani
      • Anterior belly of digastric
      • Mylohyoid

Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking syndrome:

  • About 5% of all cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.
  • The vast majority are unilateral.
  • Etiology: a branch of the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.
  • Signs
    • Retraction of the ptotic lid in conjunction with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement.
    • Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth.
    • Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it.
